page.title: 10Local History in Oakley
page.content: Oakley was once part of the Bernwode Forest. Oakley derived its name from the Saxon words Aclin or Achlaie which meant oak trees and a plain. The school was built in the 18th Century,and would have been a lace school.In 1859 a brick and stone school was built,there was a house for the teacher adjoining, which was later struck by lightning. No one was hurt. The school was enlarged in 1884. It closed in 1959 when a new school was built. Deliveries in the village used to be by pony and cart. The Worminghall Road was known as "Uptown". There was a sweet shop in Mill House. Roman pottery and coins have been found at Ixhill Farm which is thought to have been a Roman Villa.
